attributes.title: Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
•    On 28th May 2025, a physical stock count of raw materials and finished products was carried out at the Nakuru branch to verify inventory accuracy by comparing physical counts with SAP system records and to evaluate the adequacy and effectiveness of existing stock control measures.
•    A few discrepancies in the inventory records were observed as illustrated below:
a)    Bread stock had a surplus  of 137.50 Pieces,
b)    Polybags had a surplus of 1,851 pieces,
c)    White flour had a surplus of 7.05 kgs,
d)    Wheat bran had a surplus of 2.24kgs,
e)    Brown flour had a negative variance of 6.28kgs,
f)    Utto had a negative variance of 2.17 litres,
g)    Other stock items had minimal variation as illustrated below;
 

Crates Movement.
•    A physical count of crates at the branch was conducted to assess the effectiveness of crate movement controls.
•    The results indicated that there were opening balance amounting to 87 crates nonetheless, the crates balance tallied.


 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Verification of Damaged Polybags Records
•    A physical spot check of damaged polybags from the first shift on May 29 2025, was carried out at the branch. The purpose was to check whether the damaged polybags were being correctly recorded in the shift-wise damaged polybags book, which is later used for updating the system records.
•    During the audit, several inconsistencies were found. The actual weights of some damaged polybags did not match the figures recorded in the book. From the sample checked, there were significant discrepancies with some entries greatly overstating the amount of damaged polybags in the system. Items with major variances are as shown below;
attributes.recommendation:
•    Branch management should ensure that yield recording is performed accurately and strictly in line with established control procedures. 
•    The presence of a significant positive variance in bread stock suggests that either yield was not recorded correctly or inter-branch transfer controls were not properly followed. 
•    To prevent such discrepancies, staff must consistently record production yields in real time and any transfers from other branches should be properly documented and reconciled in both the system and physical stock.
•    Regular reviews and supervisory checks should be implemented to reinforce compliance with these controls.
attributes.effect: The observed variances between physical stock and SAP records both surpluses and deficits indicate potential weaknesses in stock controls in recording, tracking, or reconciliation processes. Small inconsistencies can accumulate over time, affecting overall inventory accuracy.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Discrepancies between SAP records and physical stock (e.g., bread, flour, polybags).
Remediation Plan:

  • Reinforce real-time and accurate yield recording.
  • Properly document inter-branch transfers.

Issue: Mismatches between physically damaged polybags and recorded values.
Remediation Plan:

  • Ensure shift supervisors verify and sign off damaged polybags.

  • Update records in real time and review for consistency.

value:
•    We have noted the identified variances and will make sure that the existing controls are followed to keep them as low as possible. 
•    We will also review recorded yields to reduce any differences, and we’ll follow up on goods issued to ensure accuracy.
•    Crates balances are mainly from institutions but controls for crates are effective we shall maintain.
•    Supervisors will be advised to ensure correct recordings are done for all the damaged polybags after every shift.

•    Branch manager to check bread variances and other items so as to avoid variations.
•    The branch’s daily production must match the expected output shown in the mixing chart and SAP system.
•    Manager to increase surprise checks to catch and fix any wrong yield recordings
•    We shall maintain Inventory control for Crates balance.
•    Polybags were issued without matching the physical stock this needs to be corrected.

•    In the prior audit report dated 14th   April 2025 stock take reveled the following:
a)    Polybags +688 Pieces.
b)    Bread stock had a negative variance of 91 Loaves.
c)    White flour had a variance of +10.07 Kgs equivalent to 38 Loaves.
d)    Wheat Bran had a variation of +8.357.
e)    Yeast had a variation of -3.828 pieces while all other materials had negligible variations.
f)    Crates had nil variance.

A physical stock count of raw materials and finished products was conducted on 28th May 2025. This aimed to evaluate inventory management accuracy and identify any discrepancies that may impact cost control and production.

Minor variances were observed in several items including bread, flour, and polybags. Although crates were properly managed, discrepancies in yield recording and damaged polybags indicate the need for tighter control and improved real-time documentation.
Operations/Production Department
To verify the accuracy of inventory records by comparing physical counts against SAP system data, and to assess the effectiveness of stock and crate controls.

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
•    An analysis of both mixing chart and mixing chart summary was done for a period of 31 days from 28th April 2025 to 28th May 2025.
•    This analysis aimed to assess whether the average yield per production bag and actual Utto consumption aligned with the set BOM, evaluate the full utilization of branch production capacity and ensure compliance with quality standards.
•    The analysis revealed the following:
a)    Utto consumption stood at 100%.
b)    The average yield was 191.46 loaves per bag.
c)    Average production was 86.19 bags per day, this represents 76.96% of the set target of 112 bags.
d)    There were 91 remixes for the period audited.
•    Below is a summary of the audit finding:
 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

•    Daily production was moderately adjusted to match market demand, supported by inter-branch transfers. During the period, the branch received a total of 45,692 loaves through inward transfers.
•    The summary below provides an analysis comparing average daily production against market demand.
attributes.recommendation:
•    Branch management should review and revise daily production planning to ensure better alignment with demand and optimal use of capacity.
•    It is also important to implement a preventive maintenance schedule to reduce the frequency of machine breakdowns.
•    While inter-branch transfers are necessary at times, the branch should aim to meet most of its demand through its own production by improving operational efficiency and production planning.
attributes.effect:
•     The branch lack of target attainment indicate underutilization of available production capacity. This limits efficiency and may affect the branch's ability to meet market demand consistently without relying on inter-branch transfers.
  • A substantial number of loaves (45,692) were received from other branches to meet sales demand, highlighting the branch's dependence on external support rather than internal production sufficiency.
  • Machine breakdowns, although addressed on a case-by-case basis, contributed to the production shortfall.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Underutilization of production capacity; overreliance on inter-branch transfers.
Remediation Plan:

  • Improve daily production planning to meet market demand.

  • Implement preventive maintenance to reduce downtime.

  • Align production with sales trends.

value:
•    Production during the period was adjusted in response to low sales, which resulted in not fully meeting our production targets.
•    Additionally, instances of machine breakdowns though repaired on a case-by-case basis further impacted our ability to achieve the planned production levels.
•    There were also noted cases of remixes involving machine breakdowns

•    A request was made to align the Bill of Materials (B.O.M), and it has now been successfully aligned.
•    Production targets were not met because bread production was controlled based on the sales order.
•    Regular follow-ups were done with the K.A.F department for preventive maintenance.

•    In Prior Audit, audit findings were as follows: 
    Average production was 93.68 bags equivalent to 83.65% of the set target of 112 bags.
    Utto units consumption to bags of flour ratio was 1:1
    The average yield was 191.5 loaves per bag.
Mixing charts for 28th April to 28th May 2025 were reviewed to determine whether actual production aligned with capacity targets and ingredient use standards.

The branch achieved only 76.96% of its daily production target. Machine breakdowns and reliance on inter-branch transfers point to underutilization of internal capacity, requiring better planning and preventive maintenance.
Operations/Production Department
To evaluate production efficiency by analyzing ingredient usage, yield per bag, and remix incidents against the BOM and production targets.

attributes.title: Cash Verification.
attributes.description:
•    As part of our routine checks, a cash verification was carried out to confirm that the physical cash on hand matched the recorded cash balance in the cash flow records. This was also intended to assess the effectiveness of cash handling and management controls.
•    At the time of our audit, we identified a variance of Kshs 331,920, representing funds still reflected in the cashflow records but which had been misappropriated by a former cashier.
Implication:
•    The identified variance of Kshs 331,920 indicates a serious lapse in cash handling controls and points to potential misappropriation by a previous cashier. This raises concerns about fraud, weak oversight and bypass of existing cash control at the branch.
•    The continued reflection of the misappropriated amount in the cash flow records without resolution suggests that corrective and disciplinary measures have not been fully enforced, which could encourage further misconduct if not addressed.
attributes.recommendation:
•    Collaborate with the Operations and teams to complete the investigation into the misappropriation and initiate recovery procedures, including disciplinary action and possible legal steps against the responsible party.
•    Branch management should also enforce strict cash handling procedures, including daily cash reconciliations, dual sign-offs and regular surprise cash counts to deter future irregularities.
attributes.effect:
•    The identified variance of Kshs 331,920 indicates a serious lapse in cash handling controls and points to potential misappropriation by a previous cashier. This raises concerns about fraud, weak oversight and bypass of existing cash control at the branch.
•    The continued reflection of the misappropriated amount in the cash flow records without resolution suggests that corrective and disciplinary measures have not been fully enforced, which could encourage further misconduct if not addressed.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Ksh 331,920 misappropriated by a former cashier, still unrecovered.
Remediation Plan:

  • Finalize investigations and pursue recovery and legal action.

  • Strengthen cash controls with dual sign-offs and daily reconciliations

value:
•    The variance identified in the current cash movements at the branch is minimal.
•    Regarding the misappropriated cash, we will coordinate with the Operations team to determine the appropriate way forward.

•    The cash shortfall is partly due to a previous cash stock difference, and the case is still under review. 
•    Other than that, cash recording and cash flow are being managed properly.
•    In prior audit, there was a variance amounting to KES 331,920 still pending in the cash flow records attributed to lost cash by a previous cashier with a pending case.
A spot check on cash was done as part of standard internal controls. The audit verified whether the actual cash matched the book balance and checked for any undocumented transactions.

The physical cash matched the recorded cash balance, indicating that controls are functioning well. However, there were two pending IOUs that need prompt follow-up to avoid future reconciliation issues.
Operations/Production Department
To confirm that the physical cash held at the branch matches the recorded balance and to assess adherence to proper cash handling procedures.

attributes.title: Bread weight analysis.
attributes.description:
•    A spot check was conducted on 28th May 2025 to assess whether the weight of packed bread, ready for market dispatch, complied with the required KEBS standard weights. 
•    The audit involved sampling various bread types to evaluate weight accuracy.
•    The analysis revealed notable instances of non-compliance, particularly underweight products across several bread varieties. While some samples met or exceeded the required weight, a significant portion fell below the standard weight.
•    Summary of findings:
attributes.recommendation:
•    Branch management should implement regular in-process weight checks at key points in the production line to ensure all bread varieties meet the required KEBS standard weights.
•    It is recommended that branch management take measures to control the jams caused by slow packing by the packers which can also contribute to weight compliance issues.
attributes.effect:
•    Inconsistent product weights indicate non-compliance with standard operating procedures and a lack of control in the production process.
•    Under-weight products may result in customer dissatisfaction and loss of consumer trust affecting sales and brand credibility.
•    Overweight products increase production costs and reduce overall profitability by consuming excess raw materials.
•    Failure to meet KEBS weight standards could lead to regulatory penalties, reputational damage, and potential financial losses.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Significant instances of underweight and overweight bread.
Remediation Plan:

  • Perform routine in-process weight checks.

  • Address slicer and packing delays.

  • Ensure staff follow FIFO and production standards.

value:
•    The FIFO (First-In, First-Out) process was not consistently followed, particularly during instances of production jams caused by slow slicer performance.
•    Moving forward, we will closely supervise these situations to ensure FIFO compliance.
•    We also plan to balance the use of slicers more effectively i.e. best performing with slow performing slicers, as slicer-related delays are contributing to production slowdowns.
•    The Branch Manager and C.H.B have already been instructed to follow the FIFO method for all inventory stocks

•    The previous audit report dated 14th   April 2025; underweights percentage noted were as follows:
a)    400g Ct-1%,
b)    400g Barrel-13%,
c)    600g Barrel-48%,
d)    800g-35%.
•    Overweight across the branch variety were as shown below:
e)    400g Ct-12%,
f)    400g Barrel-10%,
g)    600g Barrel-13%
A sample weight check was performed on various bread types ready for dispatch. The test sought to assess compliance with standard bread weights and detect production inconsistencies.

High rates of underweight products were found, especially for 400g and 800g varieties. This raises concerns over equipment performance and process consistency. Calibration of weighing scales and oven efficiency must be prioritized.
Operations/Production Department
To verify if all bread produced complies with KEBS weight standards and to ensure quality consistency across varieties.

attributes.title: Bread damages Percentage Analysis
attributes.description:
•    An analysis was done on the bread damage levels for both production and market-based damages for the period 28th April 2025 to 28th May 2025 to detect if the quality standards set for the branch were being followed.
•    We noted the following:
a)    Production bread damages stood at 0.23% of total production which was slightly above the set limit of 0.2% 
b)    Market damage stood at 0.69% of total sales, which was within the set limit of 0.5% as demonstrated in the table below:
 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

NB. Oven-related damages (63 loaves) were excluded from the analysis.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

•    An in-depth analysis of bread returns from supermarkets revealed returns reasons across multiple supermarket chains, with the largest contributors being Naivas Ltd and Quickmart Ltd. These reasons are as detailed below:
a)    Expired Products& Short expiry: This was the leading cause of returns, suggesting challenges with inventory rotation and short shelf-life
b)    Market damages: Bread returned due to physical deformities or packaging issues upon arrival points to production or logistics related handling issues.
c)    Ordered but Not Delivered: Mainly due lack of bread variety ordered
attributes.recommendation:
•    Branch management should conduct routine checks during mixing, baking and packing stages to detect and correct deformities early.
•    Branch management should also implement regular inspection and maintenance of baking tins, slicing machines to avoid damage caused by worn or defective equipment.
attributes.effect:
•    The branch production damage rate indicates a deviation from the branch's internal quality benchmarks signaling inefficiencies in the production process.
•    Previous use of poor-quality tins contributed to product deformities, affecting both production output and potentially leading to increased returns or customer dissatisfaction.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Slightly above-target production damage; market damages near the limit.
Remediation Plan:

  • Improve tin quality and handling during baking.

  • Align production with actual orders to reduce expiry.

  • Increase quality control spot checks.

value:
•    We previously experienced production damages due to the use of poor-quality tins.
•    However, new tins have since been received, and we will work towards improving product quality and minimizing production damages to the lowest possible levels.
•    Additionally, there was a high rate of expiry for brown bread, which resulted from producing more than the orders received. To address this, we have adjusted our production approach by using the barrel production producing half brown and half white bread based on actual orders.
•    We pack bread based on orders received. Going forward, we will align production strictly with actual orders.

•    The production procedure must be strictly followed, including properly dividing product ranges by variety. The required number of tins shall be kept in rotation as per the production plan.
•    Spot checks and the overall production process will be closely monitored.
•    Quality inspections through spot checks shall be increased.

•    During the prior audit dated 14th April 2025, it was noted that;      
a)    Production damages were 0.285% of the total production,
b)    Market damages were 0.78% of the total sales.
An analysis covering May 2025 assessed damage percentages from production processes and from returns in the market, to determine the effectiveness of quality control measures.

Both production (0.29%) and market (1.35%) damage levels exceeded set limits. Production inefficiencies and poor post-production handling are key contributors. Corrective action is necessary to minimize financial losses and protect brand integrity.
Operations/Production Department
To evaluate levels of bread damage during production and distribution, and compare them against Key Performance Indicators (KPIs).

attributes.title: Damages sent to Ingredients’ Balance Analysis
attributes.description:
•    An audit verification was conducted on 28th May 2025 to confirm that all bread damages declared as sent to the ingredients department were either physically available or correctly accounted for according to the established procedures.
•    The review covered the period from 28th April to 28th May 2025 and identified a variance of 50 kg, equivalent to 126 loaves, which could not be accounted for in either physical stock or recorded.
•    Additionally, it was noted that some instances of moldy bread disposal were not recorded, indicating gaps in documentation and accountability
attributes.recommendation:
•    Branch management should ensure all bread damages, including those sent to the ingredients department and moldy disposals, are promptly and accurately recorded in the designated book.
•    Branch management should also regularly analyze damage and disposal trends to identify patterns or recurring issues and take corrective action where needed.
attributes.effect:
•    The unaccounted 127 loaves represent a loss of both product and value, suggesting weak internal controls in handling and recording bread damages.
•    Failure to record disposed moldy bread and transferred damages undermines the integrity of inventory records and hinders effective tracking and reconciliation.
•    Inadequate oversight in the handling of bread damages increases the risk of unauthorized diversion or misappropriation of stock.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: 127 loaves unaccounted for; some moldy disposals not recorded.
Remediation Plan:

  • Accurately document all damaged and disposed items.

  • Perform periodic reconciliations to detect discrepancies early.

value:
•    Cases of moldy bread that were disposed of were not recorded.
•    Moving forward, we will ensure proper documentation is maintained for all market returns and moldy bread disposals in accordance with established procedures.
•    Managers have been advised to properly record all damages to avoid discrepancies. Control measures should be strengthened to ensure accuracy.
•    In the previous audit report, for the period 1st March to 7th April 2025, damages had a variance of -437.10 Kgs equivalent to -1,092.75 Loaves.
A reconciliation of bread damages and physical stock was done for May 2025. The aim was to ensure that all damaged or returned bread was accurately tracked and transferred to ingredients or disposal.

A variance of 53kg (approx. 133 loaves) was found. This suggests weak controls in recording and tracking damages, especially for moldy or discarded bread. Proper documentation procedures must be enforced.
Operations/Production Department
To confirm that bread damage reported as sent to the ingredients department is properly recorded and accounted for.

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
•    We carried out a review to assess how well the production workforce is being utilized. The aim was to determine whether each production worker is achieving the company’s target of producing 4.5 bags, as specified in the company policy.
•    The analysis showed that the average production per worker was 4.12 bags, which is slightly below the company’s standard target of 4.3 bags per worker, as summarized below:
attributes.recommendation:
•    Branch management is recommended to align staffing decisions more closely with production targets and machine availability to avoid unnecessary labor costs.
•    Branch management should also implement a preventive maintenance program for key machinery to reduce the risk of unexpected breakdowns.
attributes.effect:
•    The below-target production efficiency indicates potential operational inefficiencies that could affect overall profitability and productivity.
•    Continued equipment downtime without on-time resolution risks disrupting production schedules and meeting customer demand.
•    The extra labor costs incurred due to overstaffing highlight a misalignment between workforce planning and actual production needs, leading to increased operational expenses.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Actual output per worker (4.12 bags) was below the 4.5 target.
Remediation Plan:

  • Optimize staffing based on machine availability.

  • Implement scheduled maintenance to reduce breakdowns.

value:
•    Production efficiency was impacted by the breakdown of the oven and mixer, which prevented operations from running at full capacity.
•     Although the issue was reported promptly, the response took approximately four days. 
•    The problem has since been resolved, and we are now operating at full capacity.
•    Need to improve on this, will take measure to encounter this issue.
•    The previous audit report indicated a production efficiency of 4.34 bags per production worker.
Production staffing and output for May 2025 were analyzed to evaluate workforce utilization and cost efficiency. The focus was to identify overstaffing or operational inefficiencies.

The branch achieved 4.21 bags per worker, slightly below the target. Overstaffing and machinery breakdowns were identified as major contributors. Staffing should be aligned with actual needs and preventive maintenance should be improved
Operations/Production Department
To determine if the number of production workers aligns with actual output, based on the company’s benchmark of 4.5 bags per worker.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency.
attributes.description:
•    An assessment was carried out to evaluate the efficiency of packers in the slicing section, focusing on whether they met the company’s standard target of 97 crates per packer.
•    The analysis covered a period of 31 days from 28th April 2025 to 28th May 2025. The results showed that the average packing efficiency was 82.93 crates per packer, which is below the target, as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation:
•    Branch management should review and adjust staffing levels regularly to align packer numbers with actual production volumes, avoiding unnecessary labor costs.
•    Management should also introduce regular performance evaluations for slicers and packers. Rotate slower performers with higher achievers and provide targeted training to boost overall productivity.
attributes.effect:
•    The shortfall in packing efficiency indicates a mismatch between workforce allocation and actual production output, resulting in unnecessary labor costs and reduced cost-effectiveness.
•    The continued employment of underperforming slicers and packers points to insufficient performance monitoring and lack of corrective action and or training, which may contribute to long-term inefficiencies.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Average crates packed per worker below target (82.93 vs. 97).
Remediation Plan:

  • Monitor performance of  packers.

  • Offer training and rotate staff to balance performance levels

value:
•    Slow performance from some slicers has also contributed to the issue. 
•    To improve efficiency, we will rotate well-performing slicers with slower performers to balance productivity.
•    We are aware of the issue and training programs are being increased to improve slicing efficiency.
•    The previous audit report indicated a packing efficiency of 92.71crates per packer.
Packing efficiency was evaluated for May 2025 to determine if labor resources were optimally used and if equipment or process issues affected productivity.

The branch achieved 84.36 crates per packer, well below the target. Staffing was excessive and equipment breakdowns affected performance. Regular monitoring and timely maintenance are needed to boost output
Operations/Production Department
To assess whether packers in the slicing section meet the company’s productivity target of 97 crates per packer.

attributes.title: Mini shop
attributes.description:
•    A spot check was conducted at the Mini Shop on 29th May  2025, to verify that all bread available for sale was properly recorded and to confirm that reported sales matched the amounts received through the assigned pay bill number, since the shop operates on a cashless basis.
•    We found that all sales recorded up to the time of the spot check were accurate.
•    In addition, the physical bread stock, including all deliveries and top-ups, was present as expected excluding the quantities already sold.
•    However, there was a payment of Ksh 70 for a Mibisco product that caused a variance between the total sales and the amount received through the M-Pesa paybill, as detailed below.
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management should continue enforcing the current stock tracking and cashless sales controls as they are effective in ensuring accuracy and transparency.
attributes.effect: •    The effective stock controls in the Mini Shop indicate that all sales and bread movements are accurately recorded, minimizing discrepancies
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: A Ksh 70 variance due to a cash purchase in a cashless system.
Remediation Plan:

  • Maintain and enforce strict cashless policy.

  • Train staff on how to handle exceptional cash transactions properly.

value: •    Controls in place shall be maintained.
•    Controls in place shall be maintained.

•    In prior audit, sales done at the time of the spot check had a variance of +104 from the till account balance attributed to advance paid by a customer, however, all the expected bread balances from loading done exclusive of sales were physically available
Previous
A spot check was conducted on 1st June 2025 to verify that bread sales and physical stock at the Mini Shop matched with Mpesa collections and system records.
Records were accurate with only a negligible variance of KES 4. The shop’s stock and sales controls are strong and should be maintained, with minor improvements to till account separation.
Operations/Production Department
To confirm the accuracy of stock movement and Mpesa sales collection in the branch’s cashless mini shop.

attributes.title: Vehicles Fuel Consumption Analysis.
attributes.description:
•    A review was conducted on the branch of vehicles’ fuel consumption to determine if there was optimal utilization of fuel for the period up to 29th  May 2025
Finding:
•    KCL 218R Town route had a faulty speedometer which has not yet been repaired.
•    Other routes fuel consumption was within the set standard as detailed in  below:
attributes.recommendation:
•    Continue issuing fuel based strictly on kilometers covered as per route. 
•    This policy has proven effective in controlling fuel use and aligning consumption with operational demands.
attributes.effect: •    The issue with the speedometer malfunction on the Town route vehicle could lead to inaccurate fuel tracking, making it difficult to monitor actual consumption and potentially masking other underlying problems.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: Faulty speedometer on one route vehicle affected tracking.
Remediation Plan:

  • Repair the speedometer promptly.
  • Continue issuing fuel based on kilometers covered.

value:
•    Controls in place shall be maintained.


•    The excess fuel consumption recorded on the Town route will be carried forward and accounted for in the following day, while fuel issuance will continue to be based on the kilometers covered.
•    Fuel consumption controls to be strengthened
•    During the previous audit it was noted that the actual fuel consumption for each vehicle was within the set standard.
The audit reviewed vehicle mileage and fuel consumption data up to 29th May 2025. It also checked for proper functioning of mileage tracking systems.
Most vehicles were within acceptable limits except one (Town route) with a faulty speedometer. This needs urgent repair to restore full monitoring capability and control.
Transport/Fleet Department
To monitor fuel usage against distance covered to detect inefficiencies or misuse, and assess vehicle tracking reliability.

attributes.title: Debtors’ Analysis.
attributes.description:
•    A review of the debtors’ balances as of 29th May 2025 was carried out to identify any outstanding amounts at the branch that may pose a risk of becoming bad debts.
•    It was noted that there were a few outstanding balances, and no dormant accounts were observed excluding institutional accounts as detailed   below,. This are debtors with outstanding balances and who were not supplied in the following days.
attributes.recommendation: •    The branch management and sales team should maintain strict debt management controls to prevent overdue balances from accumulating.
attributes.effect: •    Debt management within the branch is well controlled, with most customers having adequate security deposits.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: A few outstanding balances noted.
Remediation Plan:
•    Maintain follow-up on debt collection.
•    Ensure all customers have adequate security deposits and negotiation of favorable terms to ensure steady sale of bread

value: •    The sales representative will follow up on these outstanding accounts to ensure the balances are fully cleared.
•    Communication with the sales representative has already been made to address this issue.
•    The previous audit report indicated an outstanding debt for customers and schools amounting to KES 361,460.90
A review of the debtors' list as at 31st May 2025 was done to identify any overdue or unsecured debts and determine how well credit controls are being enforced.
Debt management is effective, with only a few pending balances and no dormant accounts. Continued vigilance is necessary to prevent credit risks.
Sales Department
To evaluate the status of outstanding customer balances and assess the risk of bad debts

attributes.title: Generator Fuel Consumption Analysis.
attributes.description:
•    We evaluated the generator's fuel consumption from May 1, 2025, to May 29 2025, to assess its efficiency and ensure it operated within expected parameters.
•    Based on the collected data, the results were deemed reasonable and consistent with the operational standards for this period as seen below;
attributes.recommendation: •    The existing controls are effective and should be strengthened to ensure fuel consumption remains within reasonable limits and that the physical fuel balance is accurately recorded.
attributes.effect: •    Controls are effective and should be maintained.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Issue: No concerns – within expected limits.
Remediation Plan:

  • Maintain current fuel monitoring and recording practices.

value: •    Controls in place are effective we shall maintain.
•    Controls in place are effective we shall maintain.
Generator use and fuel consumption from May 1–31, 2025, were analyzed to assess control effectiveness and detect any irregular usage or recording errors.
Fuel consumption was within expected parameters and accurately documented. The controls are effective and should be maintained.
Transport/Fleet Department
To confirm that generator fuel consumption is within acceptable efficiency levels and correctly recorded.
